sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Ǧīm

wib:featureValueObservation.note: found in examples, not explicitly mentioned in article
Only attested in the eastern quarter of Haifa ḥallīṣa populated by a mixture of refugees from the southern Carmel and immigrants from other areas such as Nablus who arrived in 1930
More frequent than ǧ
Less frequent than ž
Speakers of ṣaffūri only have this reflex
There is desaffrication when in contact with coronal consonants
Speakers from ʕArab əl Maslax show both ǧ and ž with a higher tendency to use ǧ by older speakers and within conversations related to Bedouin lifestyle and traditions
Speakers from ʕArab əl Maslax show variation between ǧ and ž. The use of ž is predominant among young speakers
not phonologically conditioned, but related to origin and gender of the speaker
not phonologically conditioned, but related to origin and gender of the speaker
The most frequent reflex of ǧīm is ǧ, but [gy], which is often difficult to distinguish from [g], also occurs. The reflex of ǧīm in BṢ is a very intricate problem.
Cantineau affirms ǧ is the general trend but the pronounciation of ǧ tends to evolve to /ž/
no ex
value taken from text, feature does not have a specific section in the description
We also find ǧa - yīǧi to come, el-ʕeǧel veal
y becomes i when not follwed by a vowel
žēš "army", šažara "tree", bižūz "it is possible"
rarely ž (no ex.)
it can also be ž or dy
no ex in text for this feature
Cantineau does not give ex. but says he confirms what Montagne wrote in his texts which were expected to be published soon after in the same year (always in 1936)
ḥčara stone
Behnstedt1997b no example, so I took it from Cantineau 1937
Behnstedt1997b no example, so I took it from Cantineau 1937
Behnstedt1997b no example, so I took it from Cantineau 1937
no ex
No ex
it has 2 values: gy and g
1 ex of dy: dymoli my camel
retained in neologisms, cultural words and classical contexts

cit.quote: tightly packed sticks in the ceiling

wib:featureValueObservation.note: in final pausal positions
in contact positions before a voiced consonant
in contact positions before a voiceless phoneme

The affricate ǧ (phonetically [ʤ]) is the regular reflex for *ǧ, but often friction in the release may only be minimal, especially when directly followed by alveolar consonants, which results in realizations varying between [dʒ] and [dy]

reflex for CA *ǧ is ǧ (I.P.A. [ʤ]), but the tip of the tongue is nearer to the alveolar ridge resulting in less of a resonance cavity created by the blade of the tongue. When directly preceding alveolar consonants n, I, t, d, y and r much of the friction in the release is lost, yielding a sound between [d] and [dy], and [d] with a lateral release when followed by I ... When /ǧ/ is realized intervocalically in allegro style, only minimal articulatory contact, if any, may be realized, the result being almost [y] with hardly any friction

The affricate ǧ (phonetically [ʤ]) is the regular reflex for *ǧ, but often friction in the release may only be minimal, especially when directly followed by alveolar consonants, which results in realizations varying between [dʒ] and [dy]

The affricate ǧ (phonetically [ʤ]) is the regular reflex for *ǧ, but often friction in the release may only be minimal, especially when directly followed by alveolar consonants, which results in realizations varying between [dʒ] and [dy]

The affricate ǧ (phonetically [ʤ]) is the regular reflex for *ǧ, but often friction in the release may only be minimal, especially when directly followed by alveolar consonants, which results in realizations varying between [dʒ] and [dy]

reflex for CA *ǧ is ǧ (I.P.A. [ʤ]), but the tip of the tongue is nearer to the alveolar ridge resulting in less of a resonance cavity created by the blade of the tongue. When directly preceding alveolar consonants n, I, t, d, y and r much of the friction in the release is lost, yielding a sound between [d] and [dy], and [d] with a lateral release when followed by I ... When /ǧ/ is realized intervocalically in allegro style, only minimal articulatory contact, if any, may be realized, the result being almost [y] with hardly any friction

one informant occasionally pronounced it as ž, for example: ažat ("she came"). This exception could be attributed to contact with the Galilee, but is more likely an influence of the old city dialect of Haifa
When imitating Egyptian and for some foreign words like sīgāra (cigarette) g is used.
When imitating Egyptian and for some foreign words like sīgāra (cigarette) g is used.
When imitating Egyptian and for some foreign words like sīgāra (cigarette) g is used.
When imitating Egyptian and for some foreign words like sīgāra (cigarette) g is used.
When imitating Egyptian and for some foreign words like sīgāra (cigarette) g is used.
When imitating Egyptian and for some foreign words like sīgāra (cigarette) g is used.
In a few villages, it is realised as [dɟ].
The realisation can vary between j and y. This realisation is less common than [g].
The range of palatization goes from ɟ to j.
The range of palatization goes from ɟ to j.
The affrication might also have been lost, i. e. ž.
The realisation j is preserved in foreign borrowings, mainly from Urdu and Persian, e.g. jūti ("shoes"; Urdu).
Rāǧil can both be pronounced with ǧ and j. The realisations are fluid and interchangeable.
Lijām can both be pronounced with ǧ and j. The realisations are fluid and interchangeable.
The realisation y is the most common one, in some cases it remains ǧ.
The realisation varies from j to y [j] according to the surroundings, e.g. yāyīn ("coming").

cit.quote: he will bring back to you

wib:featureValueObservation.note: In rapid speech, the phoneme might glide into a voiced palatal glide, i. e. /y/ (IPA [j]).
The phohemes j [ɟ] and ǧ [dʒ] are equally used.
Rarely occuring realisation as d: šadar (trees).
In free variation with ž.
In free variation with ǧ.
In this dialect, also *z is reflected as /ź/, e.g. xbəź "he baked"
only presumably
In the article there is also one word with /ǧ/, ǧārek "your neighbour" (p.10)
/ğ/ is also heard, especially after a dental /n/, e.g.fenğāl ‘glass’
Assimilation: ʕaǧūza > ʕžūza „mother -in-law‟

"On the other hand, I found three examples where classical /ǧ/ undergoes dissimilation to /d/ when preceded or followed by a sibilant: CA zuǧāǧun >zdāž „glass‟10, CA al-ǧazāʔiru >Dzāyəṛ „Algiers‟ 11, CA ǧāsirun >dāsəṛ „insolent, rude‟. It must be highlighted that in OA this dissimilation is not as common as it isin Moroccan dialects where classical /ǧ/ is almost always pronounced /d/ or /g/ in contact with sibilant phonemes"
When the ž is in contact with a subsequent voiceless, it is reflected as š e.g. zouštah 'his wife'
when followed immediately by a š, is may be reflected as a z e.g. zeyš army
geminated > ǧ d-ǧamaʕ mosque, sometimes in contact with r > ǧ: yxurǧu 'they go out'
ʕžūza or ʕzūza – resulted from sibilant-harmony- “old woman” and the realization [g] in ʕgūza “mother-in-law”
when geminated, then ǧ, also when in contact with /n/, /d/, /ḥ/, /​ʁ/, /ʕ/, /š/, and /f, e.g. "žinǧlan" sesame
sometimes also represented by g, in contact with sibilants, e.g. gəzzar
when geinated: ǧ
when geminated, then affricate version /ǧ/
when geminated, then ǧ
Assimilation: sibilant harmony ž > z: ʕzūza (old women); assimilation to š when followed by vioceless consonant
most frequent realisation
based on only one speaker
some instances of ǧ
